awd_titl_txt: EAGER:Novel approaches to study green leaf volatile perception
awd_abstract_narration:
Plants that are injured by herbivores emit volatile organic compounds (VOC) into the airspace which can be perceived by neighboring plants. These plants interpret the volatile compounds as alarm signals and start to upregulate defense responses against their enemies to be prepared for an impending attack. Effects of volatile compounds as inducers of defenses are well characterized, but it is unknown how plants perceive them. In general, alarm signals are perceived by dedicated receptor proteins. Most herbivore-induced volatile compounds are very small and difficult to track, which impedes the identification of their receptors. This project will develop a novel approach for labeling volatile compounds with very small tags that can be used to track the compounds and thus identify their receptors. The tagging strategy can be adapted for other small infochemicals and thus transform our knowledge of communication in plants. Identification of receptor proteins for volatile alarm signals may help to devise novel strategies for sustainable crop production by relying on innate plant defenses rather than agrochemicals. Aspects of this project will also be incorporated into an Ecology and Evolution laboratory class. In addition, undergraduates from groups underrepresented in STEM disciplines will be actively recruited to provide extra-curricular experiential learning opportunities. These students will work on VOC signaling related to this project. This will develop their practical, analytical, and communication skills, which prepares them for professional careers. In addition, two graduate students will be trained in biology and chemistry to provide a cutting-edge interdisciplinary education in chemical ecology and molecular biochemistry.

Many aspects of plant communication are mediated by volatile organic compounds such as green leaf volatiles (GLVs). When plants are injured by herbivores, they emit GLVs, which can be perceived not only by distant parts of the wounded plants (within-plant communication) but also by neighboring plants (interplant communication). Perception of these GLVs is interpreted by receiver tissues as a sign of imminent danger and results in priming or upregulation of defense responses. The objective of this EAGER proposal is to advance novel approaches to identify GLV receptor proteins that initiate defense signaling. Very small non-proteinaceous ligands like GLVs (containing only six or eight carbons) are difficult to tag and to track. This proposal takes a novel approach by using ‘click chemistry’ to couple bioactive minitagged GLVs to reporter tags in order to identify receptor proteins for GLVs. Reporters that emit fluorescent light will be used to localize the receptor-GLV-reporter complex, and biotin-based reporter tags will be used to purify this complex and to isolate a GLV receptor. Additionally, GLV-induced rapid phosphorylation-based signaling events will be determined by a phosphoproteomics approach to identify early GLV-responsive signaling proteins such as GLV receptors. Although the role of GLVs in plant communication is well documented, it is completely unknown how they are perceived by plants. This is a significant knowledge gap that hampers our understanding of GLV signaling and function. Identification and characterization of GLV receptors would transform our understanding of plant communication at the molecular and ecological level.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit
Plants, though immobile, communicate dynamically. When injured or infected, they release green leaf volatiles (GLVs) - small molecules consisting of an alcohol, aldehyde, or acetate ester group attached to a six-carbon chain - into the air. Neighboring plants perceive these volatiles as danger signals, activating their defenses. This interplant communication is highly relevant in agricultural settings, where closely spaced crops can sense GLVs from affected neighbors, boosting their innate immunity.

This project focused on labeling GLVs with "minitags" to study their bioactivity and binding in a tomato cell culture system. Minitags, such as alkyne or azide groups, consist of just two or three atoms and are compatible with "click chemistry," a bioconjugation method that allows precise labeling in biological systems. By tagging GLVs, we can identify their receptors and determine their subcellular localization.

We synthesized a library of mini-tagged GLVs and related compounds, demonstrating that modifications to the functional ethanol or ester group retained or slightly reduced bioactivity, while changes to the carbon chain significantly diminished activity. Interestingly, GLV-like fatty alcohols with longer chains (7-9 carbons) exhibited greater bioactivity than traditional C6-GLVs. We also validated click chemistry reactions in cultured plant cells and are now using fluorogenic probes, which fluoresce upon binding to minitagged GLVs, to pinpoint GLV binding sites within cells.

Another achievement was to identify proteins rapidly phosphorylated in response to GLVs using phosphoproteomics. We found that within five minutes of GLV treatment, numerous GLV-responsive phosphoproteins, including membrane-bound receptors and intracellular signaling proteins could be detected. Additional assays to test GLV responses confirmed that these phosphoproteins were also involved in responses to the defense elicitor systemin (see flow chart image). This indicates that GLVs co-opt signaling pathways activated by other elicitors of plant defenses. We are currently testing mutants for key phosphoproteins to determine their roles in GLV responses.

This project established proof-of-concept for using click chemistry in plant systems to study small molecule-receptor interactions. It has laid the groundwork for a collaborative NSF proposal focused on identifying GLV receptors. The work has already resulted in a publication in Plant, Cell & Environment (2024), a structure-activity study in Journal of Chemical Ecology, and multiple conference presentations.

Broader Impacts
The unsustainable exploitation of natural resources by modern agriculture poses a critical challenge for humanity. Sustainable development will require innovative approaches to enhance crop resilience without excessive reliance on chemical inputs. Understanding how plants communicate, particularly through GLVs, offers insights into natural defense mechanisms that could be harnessed for sustainable agricultural practices.

Our study provided a glimpse into how GLVs enable plants to respond to environmental threats. This knowledge could lead to practical applications, such as developing GLV-based strategies to boost crop immunity. By leveraging plant innate communication systems, we can reduce dependence on synthetic pesticides, promoting environmentally friendly farming practices.

Additionally, this project created valuable training opportunities for five graduate students, 13 undergraduate students, and two K-12 teachers in a highly interdisciplinary research environment. The K-12 teachers gained hands-on research experience, which they integrated into classroom activities aligned with state science standards. These educational initiatives underscore the project's broader societal impact by fostering a deeper appreciation for plant biology among future scientists and educators.

Summary
While significant progress has been made in understanding GLV emissions and responses in receiver plants, the mechanisms by which these volatiles are recognized and interpreted remain elusive. The small size and volatility of GLVs pose challenges for receptor identification using traditional labeling methods. In this project, we demonstrated the feasibility of using click chemistry to investigate small molecule-protein interactions in plant systems, advancing our understanding of how GLVs are perceived. We identified several proteins rapidly phosphorylated in response to GLV signals, offering insights into the early signaling events triggered by GLV perception.

Our findings provide a strong foundation for future research aimed at identifying GLV receptors and signaling proteins. This knowledge will deepen our understanding of interplant communication and may open new avenues for developing GLVs as tools to enhance crop immunity, contributing to sustainable agriculture.
